name: Polyphemus
title: Greek - Polyphemus
role: Son of Poseidon, One-Eyed Giant, Odysseus's Most Famous Adversary
summary: Polyphemus, the one-eyed giant (Cyclops) and son of Poseidon, features in one of the Odyssey's most famous episodes. When Odysseus and his men became trapped in his cave, the giant ate several of them before Odysseus devised his escape. By blinding the Cyclops with a heated stake and calling himself 'Nobody,' Odysseus escaped - but his boast of his true name earned Poseidon's curse that delayed his homecoming for years.
description: Polyphemus, son of Poseidon, is the one-eyed giant (Cyclops) encountered by Odysseus in Odyssey Book 9. A shepherd living in a cave, he trapped and devoured Odysseus's men until the hero blinded him with a heated stake. The 'Nobody' trick and Odysseus's later boast drive key elements of the epic's plot.

homeric_context.role_in_epic: His blinding by Odysseus causes Poseidon's wrath, the main divine obstacle to Odysseus's return

the_episode.arrival: Odysseus and twelve men enter the Cyclops's cave seeking hospitality
the_episode.violation: Polyphemus blocks the cave and eats two men each meal
the_episode.the_trick: Odysseus calls himself 'Nobody' (Outis) so the other Cyclopes ignore Polyphemus's cries
the_episode.the_blinding: Odysseus heats a stake in the fire and drives it into the Cyclops's single eye
the_episode.the_escape: Men escape clinging to the bellies of sheep
the_episode.the_mistake: Odysseus boasts his true name as he sails away

homeric_context.consequences: Polyphemus prays to his father Poseidon, who curses Odysseus to wander ten years

the_nobody_trick.description: When Polyphemus asks his name, Odysseus answers 'Nobody' (Outis in Greek)
the_nobody_trick.payoff: When blinded, Polyphemus cries 'Nobody is hurting me!' and the other Cyclopes leave him alone
